Before we get into this review, I will go ahead and say that to be fair, I'm not the biggest fan of these movies, but at the least when given the chance, I can appreciate them from an average viewpoint. But for now, we go into the film that started the franchise. With this film, I always found it to be in the middle. Not terrible. Not great. I just found it fine. I will say the kills were great and creative, the score for the movie was good, and the acting was also great. Of course, death's design can be well paced when cheating it from a teenager's premonition of a bigger event before the events that take the survivors out one-by-one. What keeps the film going is the thrill of what comes next as death, being a malevolent force that it is, tracks down and pulls the strings of its next victim. With the characters, I always thought of them being your usual high school drama set of troupes like you have your outcast, you bully, your best friend as they are written as such. I do give Alex credit along with Clear that they are better written for the script that they were given. Even enjoyed Alex the most as he's learning more about his premonitions while piecing together death's plan. I'll admit, one of the characters, Carter mostly, is one of my nitpicks. Being more of a whiner when he's nothing more but the jerk despite being played by a good actor. Like if I were to see him approach me, I wouldn't hold back to smack him back. But I digress. Also nice to see Tony Todd on the screen, rest in peace, even if it's just one screen being the coroner. I give this film six and a half car on the train tracks out of ten. 6.5/10.

'Final Destination' is top entertainment! I've been meaning to watch this franchise for ages - happy to get started. The only thing I know coming in is there's some sort of scene with a car driving behind a (presumably unsafely loaded) lorry? Presumably that's in a sequel. This is the first time I've watched Devon Sawa at this age of his, I know from watching TV's 'Chucky' that people always mention this film(s?) when talking about him. He is a well chosen lead, for sure. Ali Larter is solid too. Interesting to see Seann William Scott involved. Some of the characters behind that trio are iffy, in terms of how they are written/portrayed. Kerr Smith's Carter is mostly annoying, for example. Larter's Clear is written a bit odd around the middle part too. The bit with touching the thing (no spoilers) with Kristen Cloke's character is also silly. To be fair, it is a movie designed to be entertaining rather than being something super intricate and highly logical. It does deliver in regards to the former, the effects are great and the deaths do get nicely creative. It is well paced as well, a 90 minute run time is perfect for a film like this. I will say that the ending seemed a bit off to me (if still fun and fine), it kinda felt like the filmmakers didn't know how to end it given how the 'skipping' works and obviously they wanted to set a sequel. It's not a big issue whatsoever, it did seem a little roughly concluded though. All in all, as you can see from my rating, I did love watching it. Interested to see how the follows-up turned up, I'd imagine it's a mixed bag (at best) but time will tell.
I am glad I came back to this movie quite a bit older, but it still gets me at the edge of my seat, which is how horror should be.

It’s been 25 years and this franchise has given new meaning to the term paranoid/deepest fears From a screenplay by James Reddick he read from an article James Wong directs the first installment of this long dormant series centering around something many of us don’t consider…death itself coming after us Instead of a monster or inanimate object what if the thing stalking us was the presence of death? You can interpret it as the grim reaper The story centers on high school student Alex Browning and his classmates going on a trip to Paris, France They board the plane designated Flight 180 and Alex all of a sudden has a premonition of the plane exploding after takeoff He tries to warn everyone and he and several students leave yet the plane still takes off and explodes just like he said it would Then a few months later everyone seems to go on with their lives but all the survivors start dying off in weird accidents; Alex comes to the conclusion that the ones who survived die in the exact order they would have if they stayed on the plane They’re all on death’s list and they have to find a way to break the chain This has one hell of an opening with the plane itself The movie isn’t scary per se but takes our greatest fears amping them up by delivering the most gruesome death scenarios We never consider these every day walking outside our homes but death can strike at any moment It’s the unavoidable fateful nature of it all Maybe in death there are no accidents, no coincidences, all of our actions are based on choices from the mundane to the monumental, are we all part of death’s sadistic design? Wong’s direction has him taking all the chaos losing a loved one manifesting it physically and visibly, he has a timely examination of death and negative emotion Even the characters on the poster become empty husks as the series of events unfold It’s got a big collection of upcoming teen actors: Ali Larter, Sean William Scott, Devon Sawa, Kerr Smith, Amanda Detmer, and the late Tony Todd himself This ended up getting mixed reviews from critics and has more along the lines of an X-Files episode not being subtle with a few glaring plot holes but managed to make $112 million on a $23 million budget thanks to fan appreciation It’s also quite pressing since this was 1 year before the tragedy of 9/11, something horrific we were not ready for Gives off that sense of dread getting onto a plane now There’s some creative deaths like from Rube Goldberg elaborate set pieces, a chilling score, some fun dark humor, and a memorable performance by Todd bringing eerie gravitas that would be a frequent occurrence in later sequels With 6 films now it’s a testament to this franchise’s staying power for a studio genre picture making death quite unsettling

Final Destination kicks off with an eerie premise that immediately sets the tone for what’s to come. The plot follows a group of characters who narrowly escape a disaster, only to realize that fate doesn’t like being cheated. Instead of diving deep into the mystery of why things are happening, the movie focuses more on tension and the creative ways death finds its victims. While the concept is solid, the execution sometimes feels a bit surface-level, making it more about the spectacle than the psychological depth it hints at. The directing does a good job of keeping the suspense alive, using clever foreshadowing and unsettling visual cues to build tension. Cinematography plays into this well, with zoom-ins on seemingly random objects that later become crucial, adding an extra layer of unease. The film also makes great use of lighting and framing to amplify the feeling that something ominous is always lurking around the corner. It’s not a groundbreaking approach, but it works effectively within the horror-thriller genre. Acting is decent for the type of movie it is, with a few standout performances that help sell the fear and paranoia. The script keeps things moving, though some dialogue can feel a little forced at times. Where the movie really shines is in its sound design, using an eerie score and well-placed sound effects to enhance the tension. Overall, Final Destination is a fun, suspenseful ride that delivers on its concept, even if it doesn’t explore its deeper themes as much as it could have.

Because of Final Destination: Bloodlines releasing soon, I decided now would be a great chance to catch up on the rest of the series, as I watched the first film a bit ago. So, here's my review of the first film as I'm reviewing the others! I really enjoyed this movie but not because I thought it was scary. I found it quite funny. It's a weird concept: Death gets pissed at people escaping his wrath and punishes them via systematically killing them like an invisible slasher villain, and it's executed in a funny way. It's like a game of trying to figure out how each character on Death's hit list will die. It also has an element of dread to it, as it's still a horror movie after all. It's a film, ultimately, about fate. How your fate, no matter how hard you try to run from it, always catches up with you. It's funny and scary and I love it for that. Overall, a great horror comedy. Can't wait to watch the second one!

Not a terrible horror movie. A bunch of kids miraculously survive a brutal plane crash; and then Death and Destiny seems to be coming after them later; since they cheated Death before...Adam Stein, the director, should have reigned himself in a little; it's almost comically melodramatic sometimes. A little more nuance and subtlety, and ambiguity, would have helped. Also teenagers who aren't such a bunch of Animal House-Deadhead stereotypes. And the composer over does it with the Psycho background music...But there's still some cool ideas and set pieces nestled in there; and some good suspense. Supposedly it was inspired by an X Files script; and you can see that influence; that and The Twilight Zone; with all it's twisty stories about fate and destiny. The kill scenes are very similar to the Rube Goldberg type death scenes in The Omen. I'd recommend this for horror aficionados; and horror completists; since it's considered a classic in slasher fan circles. So not a great movie; but interesting in parts.

Comienza mi maratón de mi más grande gusto culposo del cine, la saga de Destino Final. La primera película de esta saga creo un subgénero dentro del slasher (subgénero del terror), planteando de manera clásica, la muerte de un grupo de jóvenes bajo la mano de un ser omnipresente. Ya por este aspecto, se considera un clásico del terror, pero claramente de dudosa calidad. El accidente del avión es efectivo en todo momento, donde a pesar del bajo presupuesto, tuvieron muy claro qué querían mostrar y funciona tanto en una primera vista, como en estarla repitiendo una y otra vez la escena. Con esto nos lleva a las muertes de los personajes, digamos que el desenlace de las mismas es efectivo, pero la manera en cómo empiezan, no. Detalles como el agua mágica que sale del inodoro o la taza que al mínimo cambio de temperatura se rompa (haría falta comprobarlo), hacen que estas escenas pierdan potencia, ya que, de manera contenida y no gore, logran ser efectivas e impactantes, sin mencionar que una de esas muertes es un tremendo jumpscare. Respecto a las matices de la historia, antes me parecía que hablaban mucho y no decían nada, pero ahora, algunos detalles cobran bastante sentido, como las presuntas sospechas de los agentes hacia Alex alegando que es un terrorista arraigado a los que se bajaron del avión, o del hecho que Clear no cree acerca del plan de la muerte debido al trauma que le genero la muerte de su padre y no querer aceptar un destino así; son momentos que pase muy por alto en su momento y que haberla visto después de muchos años, hacen que se le agregue un valor mas profundo a la película. Por último, voy a mencionar al elefante en la habitación, el terrible agujero argumental casi al final de la película, donde Alex se da cuenta que Clear era la siguiente y no él, ni siquiera intentaron justificarlo, fue una decisión bastante estúpida tanto de los escritores de la historia, como del mismo Alex en este universo, es completamente ridículo e incoherente y afecta muchísimo a la película, es la única razón por la cual pierde tres puntos y se queda con una calificación menguante.

Buena película, una cinta gore que es puro entretenimiento. Esta película es el inicio de una franquicia muy exitosa, con una historia que siempre me resulto entretenida de ver, a pesar de que después fue un poco sobreexplotada. Lo que me gusta de la película es que no es solo una compilación de muertes, sino que hay un trasfondo de todo lo que ocurre, y se explica bien por que pasa lo que pasa y en el orden que sucede. Esta muy bueno como el protagonista tiene las premoniciones sobre la muerte de sus amigos y es interesante ver como todos piensan que esta loco al principio y después le van creyendo. Las muertes están muy bien logradas y hay una gran variedad, algo característico de la saga. Otra cosa que me gusto fue el personaje de el forense, quien parece ser la muerte en persona según la interpretación que le das, un personaje muy interesante realmente. Por otro lado, las actuaciones están geniales, principalmente las de Devon Sawa, Ali Larter, Seann William Scott y Kerr Smith. En conclusión, una buena película, con una trama muy entretenida, unas formas de morir que quedaron marcadas y con un elenco de personajes genial. La recomiendo.

Final Destination (2000) - A Tense Journey with Pacing Quirks Released in 2000, Final Destination pioneered a unique approach to the horror genre, introducing audiences to a gripping narrative centered around the ominous concept of escaping death's clutches. While the film falls into the realm of the average, securing a 5.5 out of 10, it manages to carve out its own space with a suspenseful storyline, despite occasional pacing hiccups. Innovative Premise: Final Destination kicks off with a fresh and innovative premise, exploring the aftermath of a group of survivors who cheat death after narrowly escaping a catastrophic plane crash. The movie ventures into uncharted territory by delving into the consequences of thwarting fate, setting the stage for a suspenseful and intriguing tale. Effective Suspense and Inventive Deaths: The film excels in creating an atmosphere of constant dread, utilizing inventive and, at times, gruesome death sequences that keep viewers on the edge of their seats. The unpredictable nature of these scenarios adds an element of excitement, contributing to the overall tension that Final Destination successfully cultivates. Abit Slow Pacing: However, the movie encounters challenges with pacing. There are instances where the narrative seems to lose its momentum, leading to moments of sluggishness. These slower intervals, although a drawback, don't entirely overshadow the film's ability to maintain an underlying sense of unease. Character Dynamics and Performances: The characters, while not exceptionally deep, manage to convey the psychological toll of evading death. The cast, including Devon Sawa as Alex Browning, delivers performances that resonate with the genre's expectations, even if character development takes a backseat to the unfolding chaos. Predictable Plot Turns: While the film's premise is intriguing, the plot, at times, takes predictable turns. Some elements of the story follow familiar horror tropes, and the narrative occasionally lacks the level of complexity that could elevate it to a more exceptional status. Final Verdict - 5.5/10: Final Destination secures a 5.5 out of 10, reflecting its standing as an average horror-thriller. The movie navigates the challenging terrain of death and destiny with inventive death sequences and moments of genuine suspense. While pacing quirks and predictable elements hold it back from greatness, Final Destination manages to deliver an overall enjoyable experience for fans of the genre. It stands as a notable entry in the early 2000s horror landscape, with its own unique take on the inevitability of fate.

Final Destination is chilling, thrilling, and hilarious. Director James Wong's supernatural horror thriller Final Destination (2000) is truly awesome. Wong's moody direction is very stylized and atmospheric. I love a lot of these early 2000's movies that I grew up watching. It's not just blind nostalgia because the brutal and creative kills are super entertaining. Wong's visceral style is gripping, especially with his forlorn tone. He makes a somber and mournful tone to respect the dead as he kills off these teenagers one by one. Wong's cycles of death are enthralling. You really cannot cheat Death. Screenwriters James Wong, Jeffrey Reddick, and Glen Morgan ruminate on how you can cheat Death. Final Destination's premise of plane crash survivors getting hunted down by the Grim Reaper is interesting enough, but putting existentialist questions along the way is the icing on the cake. The amount of detail and thought put into which order of people dying or what convoluted series of coincidences have to occur before someone is killed is delightful. They come up with innovative murders that are horrifying enough to stay in your memory, but also highly enjoyable to watch in a horror thriller. The plane explosion, car crash, knife stabs, decapitation, and more are fantastic. Who can forget the exploding lights and electric shocks? Final Destination holds up for me. I love and appreciate the entire cast of characters having their last names based off of famous horror directors, actors, or producers is a fun nod. Casting directors John Papsidera and Heike Brandstatter got famous Canadian and American actors for the panicked teenagers makes for a real pleasant watch. Canadian actor Devon Sawa is amazing as Final Destination hero Alex Browning. I appreciate his freaks out performance as he gets premonitions of death and attempts to prevent his friends from being killed by the Grim Reaper. Devon Sawa was actually a great actor and not just a teen heartthrob from the early 2000's. I think he's gripping and emotionally raw throughout the entire movie. He feels totally earnest in his mourning of his friends to his fear of others getting harmed. American actress Ali Larter is gorgeous and compelling as the curiously named Clear Rivers. I had such a crush on her when Final Destination came out and she's still so pretty and engaging in this horror classic. Ali Larter feels genuine in her emotions after getting spooked by Alex's premonitions. She makes for a cute goth girl or edgy heroine. I like that she's a survivor and smart and not here just as a love interest. She has real romantic chemistry with Devon Sawa when they're talking in her garage about their connection. American actor Kerr Smith is great as the jock bully Carter Horton with a chip on his shoulder. His rage and frustrations over feeling emasculated by Alex saving him are interesting. He's such a selfish jerk. Kristen Cloke is excellent as the scared teacher Valerie Lewton with her feelings of guilt over telling the other teacher to stay on the doomed flight. Daniel Roebuck's frustrated Agent Weine and Roger Guenveur Smith's skeptical Agent Schreck are fun adults. Canadian actor Chad Donella is quite moving as Alex's guilt ridden best friend Tod Waggner. Seann William Scott is hilarious as the hysterical idiot Billy Hitchcock. Tony Todd's ominous monologue about cheating Death is outstanding as creepy coroner William Bludworth. It's like the Grim Reaper telling the heroes off for surviving so long. Amanda Detmer is really hot as the dumb blonde Terry Chaney. Editor James Coblentz' sharp cuts make each kill exciting and the movie super fast paced. Cinematographer Robert McLachlan uses heavy shadows, nighttime shots, and blue lighting for a haunting look to Final Destination. Production designer John Willett lets everything move to be potentially lethal. Art directors William Heslup and Bill McMahon lean into that slick icy lighting and sheen of early 2000's horror movies. I love the dark way Final Destination looks. Set decorators Geoff Wallace, Mary-Lou Storey, John Alvarez, Anneke Van Oort, and Joey Jow let every prop be deadly. All the practical effects and CGI look fabulous. Composers Shirley Walker and Adam Hamilton's thrilling film score is eerie with atmosphere and plenty of symphonic bursts for the horror sequences. The massive sound team of Scott Martin Gershin, Dino Dimuro, Eric Batut, Nerses Gezalyan, James Moriana, Jeffrey Wilhoit, Greg Zimmerman, Alan Rankin, Paul Timothy Carden, Tom Ozanich, Melissa Sherwood Hofmann, Brad Sherman, Hector C. Gika, Peter Zinda, Scott Wolf, Scott Sanders, Philip A. Hess, and Dave McMoyler put every noise imaginable in here. They make each moment suspenseful. Costume designer Jori Woodman gives every actor and actress the most 2000's crop tops, sweaters, and double layers of shirts. Makeup artist Lisa Love makes Ali Larter and Amanda Detmer look like the prettiest girls ever. Hairstylists Stacey Butterworth and Thom MacIntyre do the coolest haircuts for everyone that embodies that era. In all, Final Destination is a delightful 98 minutes of murder and nostalgia.

A película "Premonição", lançada em 2000 e dirigida por James Wong, apresenta uma premissa intrigante que promete manter os espectadores à beira de seus assentos. Com uma pontuação de 4 em 5, o filme oferece uma combinação de suspense, tensão e elementos sobrenaturais que cativam a atenção do público, apesar de algumas falhas que impedem uma avaliação perfeita. O enredo gira em torno de um grupo de adolescentes que escapam de um acidente de avião devido a uma visão premonitória de um dos personagens. Enquanto o grupo tenta lidar com a sobrevivência e o trauma do ocorrido, a Morte parece estar seguindo-os para garantir que a ordem natural seja restabelecida. O roteiro inteligentemente brinca com a ideia de destino versus livre-arbítrio, criando um cenário onde as vítimas lutam para escapar das garras inexoráveis da Morte. As cenas de morte são elaboradas de maneira meticulosa, com uma combinação de suspense, surpresa e horror, que são elementos-chave do gênero. A direção de Wong é habilidosa ao criar uma atmosfera de tensão crescente, mantendo o público ansioso para ver como cada personagem enfrentará seu destino inevitável. No entanto, o filme não é isento de falhas. Algumas atuações parecem um tanto artificiais, afetando ocasionalmente a imersão do público na história. Além disso, o desenvolvimento dos personagens poderia ter sido mais profundo, permitindo ao público uma conexão mais sólida com eles, o que teria intensificado ainda mais o impacto emocional das cenas de morte. Outro ponto que merece destaque é a maneira como o enredo se desenrola. Embora a premissa inicial seja intrigante, a lógica por trás das mortes muitas vezes parece forçada e improvável. Isso pode tirar parte do realismo do filme e fazer com que o público questione a coesão interna da trama. Em suma, "Premonição" é um filme que oferece uma dose saudável de suspense e horror, mantendo os espectadores entretidos ao longo de sua narrativa. Apesar de suas falhas na atuação e na construção lógica da história, ele consegue prender a atenção e proporcionar momentos de intensa emoção. Com uma nota de 4 em 5, é uma escolha sólida para os amantes do gênero que estão em busca de uma experiência cinematográfica eletrizante.

Final Destination is a horror movie with a novel idea that makes it memorable, along with its creative and gory kills that become more elaborate as the franchise continues. The acting in the film is inconsistent, ranging from passable to good, but Tony Todd's standout scene adds to the overall quality. The Final Destination franchise is a rollercoaster of hits and misses, with each film offering a unique experience. The first film was a standout with its incredible cast, well-choreographed death scenes, and impressive CGI, creating a thrilling and memorable viewing experience. It sets the stage for the rest of the franchise and is a must-watch to dive into the series. The fear-inducing nature of the first film sticks with you, making you wary of certain scenarios like logging trucks on the interstate. The subsequent films maintain the suspense and entertainment value, although some may not reach the same heights as the original. Final Destination 3 introduces a roller coaster theme, adding a new dimension to the series with a focus on amusement park thrills. While it may not live up to the standards set by its predecessors, the film still offers an engaging watch, thanks to its strong casting and visual effects. Final Destination and Final Destination 5 continue the franchise's trend of captivating audiences with their thrilling storylines and engaging characters. While they may not reach blockbuster status, they succeed in keeping viewers entertained and invested in the series. Overall, the Final Destination franchise is a mixed bag, with each installment bringing something different to the table. While some films may not shine as brightly as others, the series as a whole offers an enjoyable viewing experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat.

"We need to get off this plane, it's going to explode on takeoff and we're all going to die." Kerr Smith: "How dare you save my life." The other early 2000s horror that featured a plane explosion and turned out to age really poorly once 9/11 rolled around; you know, the one not named Donnie Darko. Final Destination has a creative premise, essentially taking the slasher out of the slasher film and replacing him with a cosmic unknown force, but I have no idea what sort of tone it's trying for here; the introduction of the film is understandably dark, condemning hundreds of people to death in a brutal explosion and dedicating a pretty substantial bit of runtime to memorials, tragic mourning, and uncomfortable unresolved trauma. The protagonist, Devon Sawa's Alex, is treated as a social pariah despite saving the lives of his friends, with his paranormal brush with death almost poisoning him in the eyes of others; even the responsibility of the first death is blamed on him, as he is accused of pushing his friend towards suicide. All signs point to a dark thriller where Alex has to contend not only with death chasing him, but a disbelieving world where he appears increasingly paranoid. Then we get ... weirdly lighthearted? The kills get elaborate and whimsical, it's like the Grim Reaper is playing with an erector set as he cobbles together each elaborate murder. Some people are just dropped from the story for laughs, usually after some ironic one-liner. By the end it's become a buddy-survival-mystery, without a hint of the paranoia that the film started out with, only hanging on to a bit of emo existentialism. It's a strange evolution that feels stark, even if the two halves kind of work on their own. Nice Tony Todd cameo, though it's a bit weird that he became a franchise mainstay when he's around for all of two minutes. Just as well that Sean William Scott's character dies here. He'd still be waiting on that Jets Super Bowl for a while yet. (2.5/5)

Final Destination is as well-acted and suspenseful as you'd expect from a movie from the writers of The X-Files that was based off of a rejected spec script for that aforementioned show though it's not without its share of weak writing and dialogue coupled with my ambivalent feelings about the two different endings. On one hand, I feel the theatrical ending fits the tone of the movie and the premise of the franchise it would spawn better. But on the other hand, there's a featurette on the DVD discussing the alternate ending's themes that made it more understandable for me. Though to be fair, I think the movie worked just fine without a love story. The characters not having much to them beyond being generic high-schoolers, and a teacher, doesn't help matters. Seems like Ali Larter was the only one who had some depth to her in one quiet scene where she talks to Devon Sawa about a family tragedy. Oh, and Tony Todd is one hell of a one-scene wonder. That clunkily inserted last sentence aside, Final Destination is a well-crafted horror-thriller whose scares come from just how easily its memorable death scenes could occur in real life, with any supernatural angle being merely implied and never outright confirmed. Critics might not have liked it all that much but it does have some intelligence lying around, a perk from having crew members from The X-Files on board, I'm guessing.

I'm not a fan of horror typically, but I was drawn to watch this because of premonitions that I had personally experienced that shook my understanding of reality. This movie goes in that direction, but in the movie, destiny is evil , unforgiving, and out to get you. Whereas in my experience, it just is. The phenomenon of clairvoyance or sixth sense is real enough for both the CIA and the Soviets to study it for decades. And there are documentaries on that. The ancient Greeks and Romans also believed in oracles--and fate. Are we meant to know everything? I don't think so. Full reality is beyond the capacity of a human brain to sense. And wouldn't it be overload? Our senses detect just enough for us to function and interact. What happens when you sense too much? Movies about that interest me. Death itself being the serial killer that is stalking and killing a bunch of kids who dodged their appointed time to die, is an interesting concept. At least it was a new spin on a horror film of this type after the glut of Scream knock-offs that had been littering theaters throughout the late 90s. However, the idea is not realized in an effective fashion with Final Destination. Considering the number of ways we all could die any given day of the week, it becomes downright comical watching the Rube-Goldberg methods that death implements to take down these kids. The movie seems to think we’re supposed to be tense and frightened when a splash of water is making its way across the floor in order to make someone slip and fall, but I could only chuckle. In fact, there’s one death that is so elaborate that I felt like it was pulled from a Naked Gun movie. There were definitely other times when the film went so over-the-top that it felt like they were going for comedy. The most blatant is the ridiculous scene in the morgue where Tony Todd explains the premise of the film for us in case we didn’t understand yet. Maybe the tone would have worked better if they hired at least one good actor. However, Final Destination is overflowing with young people straight out of Central Casting. Not one of them effectively conveys an emotion, with the possible exception of Ali Larter who might be trying a little bit. Devon Sawa, who plays the lead character, is arguably the worst of the bunch. There’s nothing likable or endearing about his performance, to the point that I was kind of rooting for him to die earlier. I can applaud the attempt these film-makers made to think outside the box, but the end result of Final Destination is not good.

Somewhere buried deep in the film's premise lies the kernel of an intriguing idea - and that's Final Destination's lone good point. What happens if someone on board a plane has a premonition of disaster, flees from the aircraft before takeoff, then watches in horror as it explodes once it is airborne. Of course, it takes about ten minutes for it to become apparent that Final Destination is only going to use this as a hook. The point of the movie has nothing to do with how the survivors cope with guilt and uncertainty. Instead, Final Destination is intent upon illustrating that, while it's possible for seven people to cheat death by disembarking from a doomed plane, the Devil still demands his due. So, with John Denver singing in the background, they start dying one-by-one. Even the special effects are no good. Near the beginning of the film, as Sawa's character, Alex, has a vision of the plane's destruction, we are treated to the same kind of visuals used several decades ago when Christopher Reeve's Superman took to the air. Later, for a beheading scene, the decapitation is so ineptly done that I found myself choking back laughter. Moments like that make you wonder if this film could have had a chance as camp. Unfortunately, the somber, serious tone deflates any hope of this.

They get gory and more gruesome as the series goes on, but theyâ(TM)re mostly realistic and look good here. One character gets beheaded and it looks way better than it has any right to in 2000. The movie also works as a good time capsule for the era it was released in. Lastly, I appreciated that the movie mostly didnâ(TM)t try to do too much. Itâ(TM)s just a fun, guilty pleasure. Weaknesses: Some of the scenes are way over dramatic and come off as cheesy. The big climax where Alex saves Clear will make your eyes roll with how lame it is. Not only does it come across as lame, but it feels unsatisfying and not the way you want things to end. Other than the cast I mentioned, everyone else is doing a pretty bad job. Seriously, thereâ(TM)s poor line delivery and bad acting galore. Overall: As I said, this is a guilty pleasure. Itâ(TM)s not going to wow you with acting or writing. It is cheap fun thanks to a really cool concept and mostly strong execution.

'FINAL DESTINATION' was directed by James Wong and stars Devon Sawa, Ali Larter and Kerr Smith. ?After a student(Devon Sawa) visions the plane he's about to board explode, he throws a fit and gets him and a group of his friends kicked of the flight. Second into the air, the plane explodes. All seems fine but when the survivors begin getting knocked off one by one, they must band together to discover the truth. Don't watch this movie if you're looking for a genuinely frightening and scary experience - you WILL be disappointed. This movie is more comedic than anything. I laughed so much more than I felt frightened. Now I think about it, I wasn't frightened at all. I wasn't even disturbed by the deaths. It was all just kind of dull. Watch this movie if you're drinking with friends because you will have a laugh, just don't watch it if you're looking for a horror movie. I really like the gimmick of this movie. It's pretty interesting and I would love to see it be explored more, with a different cast and director. The actual story itself was very poorly written. Character's are stupid and this makes it very hard to care about them. A lot of the things that happen in this movie make no sense and the deaths itself contain no logic behind them. I understand they tried to excuse it but there should still be logic and setup to each kill to justify it. Maybe even include red herrings; keep the viewer guessing. Another flaw with the deaths is how generic and boring they are. Needless gore and violence is the one thing I would remove from movies today if I could; it's sick and never works. That said, I would have actually liked to see more creativity and thought put into the deaths. Keep it comic violence and make the movie a full blown comedy; that'd be fun. The only performance in this movie that wasn't completely robotic and forgettable was Kristen Cloke as Valerie Lewton. Even that performance was just barely passable. The rest of the acting was pathetic. Devon Sawa was shocking, Ali Larter was abysmal, Kerr Smith tried but failed - no one impressed me and only one person barely escaped my scold. Every movie like this were the cast are getting picked off one by one needs to include likable characters to make me want them to live or an interesting antagonist to make the deaths interesting. This movie succeeds at neither. The characters are dull, bland and forgettable, and the antagonist(I won't spoil it) doesn't appear for the entirety of the movie. This lack of good characters makes me actively dislike the characters and means I don't care if they die which means I have lesser interest in the movie. This movie hit the trifecta of trashy cinematography. It was badly lit, shot and edited. Nothing in this movie is technically proficient. The effects are also atrocious. I don't care if it was made in the year 2000, realistic dinosaurs were made in 1993. This movie was not at all frightening(if anything, it was comedic). I laughed a lot in this movie due to the clichés and lack of genuinely frightening moments. There is a scene towards the end were I should have been on the edge of my seat but I was on the verge of crying with laughter. For what this movie is attempting to do, it fails. But for sheer entertainment value, I'll recommend this movie. Watch it with some friends. I'll rate it 3 Expert Getaway Strategies out of 10.

This film had a definitely inserting concept, that a group of teens who have "cheated" death after abruptly departing an airplane that ends up exploding upon takeoff, who then find themselves fighting for their lives as death stalks them in the form of a series of elaborate fatal and/or near fatal accidents and mishaps (ranging from seemingly simple bathroom slip and falls, to downed power lines, to elaborate car and train sequences). The film was written and directed by "X-Files" veterans Glen Morgan and James Wong, so from a technical standpoint, it's a well crafted film with excitement, suspense, and thrills. However, I'm not sure the film's premiss was enough to sustain a feature length film. It also doesn't help that the characters are not all that interesting, though it is kind of fun to see a young Ali Larter. Overall, this film this lacked story and characters to sustain itself, but the elaborate death sequences were interesting and suspenseful enough to hold my interest and make the film worth watching.

Ah, yet another fine premise hindered by horrible execution. Final Destination, the film that spawned four subsequent installments, may be dumb, but it's dumb fun nonetheless. Sure, it's basically no different than thousands of other young adult movies about kids who have amazing powers (Harry Potter, Percy Jackson, etc), but Destination seems to understand why movies like those are so bad, and even play off of them a little. It's not a spoof, but parts of it are so ludicrous and hilariously over-the-top, it's hard not to laugh. Final Destination stars a plethora of child actors (most of whom will be recognized by any X-Files aficionados out there) as a group of French class students. While en route to Paris for a school trip, a student named Alex has a prophetic vision that the plane they are on will crash, causing him to leap out of his seat, cause a panic, and get off the plane with a few of his classmates. Of course, as it always is in these kinds of movies, Alex is right and the plane blows up on takeoff. This is an epic premise, and gives way to an astoundingly awesome series of events that pits Alex against the FBI, who clearly think the circumstances are a bit suspect. It's got a little bit of that 'question authority' factor that I (as a teenager) enjoy so much in movies. But a lot of the acting is pretty bad, especially from the main characters. It's not like you're supposed to really take the movie seriously, but most of the characters overemphasize their dialogue, making the whole thing feel more like an MTV video than a serious horror movie (which it isn't). This is pretty much the horror equivalent of a Michael Bay movie: Character development is virtually nonexistent, but for clean and unbridled craziness, this is what you want. The deaths themselves are amazingly ludicrous, to the point of outright slapstick humor. I never thought I'd laugh out loud at a woman being impaled by a set of kitchen knives, but I definitely did here. Sadly, this was not really the filmmaker's intent, because the movie is SUPPOSED to be truly scary. However, it's hard to be terrified when you're watching a guy slip on toilet water, fall into his shower, and get strangled by the shower curtain. Not to mention a girl who walks into the street, says "You can all drop dead," and then gets hit by a bus. Shock humor is fun, and this movie utilizes it to no end. By the time the final sequence rolls around (which involves a clothesline and lightning), you're watching a movie so gleefully ridiculous you can't help but enjoy it. But at its core, Final Destination is really nothing more than an empty, fluffy film that just so happens to have an intriguing premise. There's not much else that sets it apart from the pack, no memorable scenes, bad acting, bad dialogue, and some pretty dumb sequences. It pains me to say this, because I actually had fun watching it, but it's nothing more than nonsensical gore and asinine plot points. Its central premise relies on the characters finding messages that death itself sends them, but why does death have a plan OR pattern, and if it did, why would it share it with them? Cheating death is one thing. Cheating the audience, though... that's the anus of cinema. Final Score for Final Destination: 4/10 stars. Much like Kick-Ass, Pacific Rim, and Event Horizon, this is an immensely entertaining movie to watch, and the perfect bargain-buy horror movie rental for a slow weekend. Sure, it's filled with obnoxious characters and confusing death sequences, but that's what movies like this are made for: Hilarious in-home commentary. It's by no means a good movie. However, for outside-the-box concepts and chaotic gore, there's no better place to turn to.

American horror is so often about visible threats that it comes as a bit of a relief to have one film feature an ominous enemy that is never seen, nor heard, norgiven shape. The premise: Devon Sawa plays a high school student who after boarding a plane on route to a high school field trip, has a horrific premonition that causes him and a group of classmates to be expelled from the plane before take-off. True to what he foretold, the plane blows up (in a very shocking scene that cannot be shaken off so easily). The survivors then find themselves being picked off one by one in a certain sequence by what seem to be freak accidents, except Candyman's Tony Todd, obviously relishing his cameo as the mortician-from-hell, warns Sawa and Larter that Death's design has been foiled, and that he is now after them and the remaining survivors. I might have preferred it if director James Wong had gone for creepiness and a strong deniability of the supernatural elements in the film, but instead he goes down the route of slam-bang, in-your-face thrills and shocks. Fortunately, it's not a full-on missed opportunity as we do end up getting a string of entertaining set pieces that cleverly show how mundane household objects can become dangerously lethal in a matter of seconds. As a viewer I soon found myself watching every scene as a potential sandbox of death - which was strangely fun. True, the film is a little ham-fisted in execution on many levels, but it also tries earnestly to rise above the typical slasher movie, which is something that needs to be appreciated.

That premise...it seems like the ideal plot for a great horror film. With such premise, you can create suspense, thrill, chills, fear and even some drama, and then have some creative deaths. I'll admit it, the film did have some atmosphere of fear and despair, but overall, it's just an averagely executed idea that doesn't scare and doesn't create any drama. It falls into the same clichés that every horror movie with teenager characters falls into: the characters are stale and dumb, like, just because they are underage. It doesn't help that the acting is very average too. We have each of these generic characters: the main character that wants to do everything right, the douchebag, the hot girl, the bully, the dumb, etc. Nothing new here. The story had an interesting development, but that alone needs characters to fully exploit its elements. Seeing how bad these characters are, you can easily guess the result. It gets a bit silly at times and predictable: they're all gonna die, so every scene in which they save one another are pointless. Now, the highlight: the death scenes. Yeah, some of them are creative, gory, and even cool. But that's the problem: they're not scary. They're just...gory, graphical, but nothing really compelling. Also it transforms everyday stuff into a deadly trap, and it isn't scary, it's silly. I did felt anxious while the movie showed the build-up to the death of certain characters, but after the fun moment of watching them die, it feels empty. And I don't even know if I were supposed to feel anxious or it's because the movie is annoying; something tells me it's the second one, but then again, maybe the movie did have something in there. Some of its moments work, but overall, it's not what it could have been. It should've been a horror classic, but it's only the beginning of a dreadful saga that overstayed its welcome at the very first sequel. Overall, it's just dumb fun, but it shouldn't be; it should be scary and suspenseful. Guess it didn't work. Well, it won some good money, so I guess people really liked this stuff. Well, unfortunately that meant a lot of sequels, each of them worse...ish. It never needed a sequel; it never needed to have numbers in the box-office either. Guess the death sentence was for us.

From the opening titles it's clear Final Destination is a film about death and the makers really lay it on thick as if the audience is incapable of following a storyline without constant reminders about the subject. There are images of death, deathly screams, even a copy of Death of a Salesman. In the beginning we join Alex (Devon Sawa) a superstitious 17-year-old who is preparing to go to France on a school field trip. "You've got your whole life ahead of you," says his dad, like a black cat crossing his path to smash a mirror over his head. When Alex and his classmates arrive at the airport, director James Wong continues to treat you like the big idiot you are. Alex is handed a 'Death is not the end' flyer and the camera zooms in on the word terminal. Numbers are significant throughout the film, as if to say your number's up. Before the flight takes off, Alex has a premonition that it's going to blow up. He and some of the other students are subsequently removed from the plane and are sitting in the lounge in time to see it explode in a fireball. But there's no escaping death and one-by-one the grim reaper picks off the survivors. You spend most of the film trying to guess how they are going to die and Wong often leads you down the wrong path ­- like when Tod (Chad Donella) starts to shave and nicks his neck and then plucks his nose hairs with a pair of sharp scissors - neither of these things get him but you're made to think they will and you start to see danger everywhere. It's after the death of his friend that Alex starts to piece together the clues: "Death has a new design for all of you." When Final Destination was released in 2000, it was an original concept. It went on to win awards, including the Best Performance by a Younger Actor, and spawned a series of films. But it hasn't aged well and when you watch other horror films it seems rather tame in comparison.

Final Destination is a really interesting film. It's got an interesting premise and is also very original. The film focuses on a group of high school students who are taking a trip to Paris and one of the students has a premonition about the plane exploding in midair. After he and a group of fellow students are taken out of the plane, the plane explodes, though the other students who left early survive. Death than starts to kill off each student who was supposed to die on the plane, in the order they were supposed to die. The death scenes are absolutely well executed, while the plane explosion is realistic and the special effects involved in it are well done. The film ends ambiguously, though on a great note with possible future events to occur.

We have so much to thank this film for, notably the four other sequels that were spawned from this classic. I wouldn't call it a horror as such as there's far more than just pointless violence or non stop scares to this, it genuinely has a credible storyline in which it just happens to encompass several grisly moments. Starting with a group of high school students who are about to embark on a trip to Paris, we then witness one of them having a premonition that the plane is about to crash. As the events in real life then begin to mirror his prediction, he has an outburst which results in several of the students having to leave the aircraft. True to form, the plane then explodes minutes later. However, that is just the beginning, as in the days after that horrific event, the survivors start dropping one by one leading the others to believe that they were destined to be on that plane as part of deaths design, and now death is hunting them down in the most gruesome of accidents. This is a very original and innovative film which keeps you guessing as to what is going to happen next, and who is in for the chop. There's nothing predictable about it, other than it will end at some point, and it is structured perfectly with an action packed beginning, eventful middle, and an unforeseeable ending sequence. There's a reason why the franchise is still ongoing over ten years later, because it would be appealing to all sexes and ages. The only time I wouldn't recommend it is for nervous flyers who are going abroad on holiday anytime soon. Aside from that, it's always a good time filler, so get on board, grab your seats, and prepare for one of the best visual journeys of a lifetime.

This is a movie which started off as a recycled screenplay for an X-Files episode, and being a huge fan of the show I could pretty much see how Mulder and Scully would fit into the plot. Setting that aside, as a horror movie this worked out quite well. It introduced something not yet seen, namely the main villain not being a monster, a killer or anything of that nature, but just death itself, and a series of over-the-top coincidences which would in some way end a person's life or mutilate their body. A fine idea which could be played with in countless ways, thus a whole franchise was born, which reminds me much of the Saw franchise due to the irony and nature of the characters' deaths.

Final Destination is one of the most surprising Horror films I've ever watched and it is also one of the best Horror films in the 21st Century. This movie is about a young man name Alex Browning who has a vision of the plane going to explode and after he saved his friends he soon realized that death is still after them and Alex and Clear Rivers must save the other survivors in order to cheat death once and for all. To be honest I had a fun time watching this movie and this movie seriously delivered the goods and its the best out of all the Final Destination films next to Final Destination 5. I seriously love this movie and I totally love the concept of death manipulating the environment in killing the survivors rather than having the grim reaper as the main antagonist instead death manipulates the environment in killing all those survivors who were supposed to die in the plane crash and I totally enjoyed this movie and it never gets boring and there are lots of big surprises that the movie delivers. What's great about Final Destination is that the whole film is full of suspense, tension and its also thrilling at the exact same time. There are lots of suspenceful scenes in this movie like the scene where Alex saves Carter Horton from getting ran over by a train in the train tracks that is one of the most suspenceful scenes in the film. The scene where Alex tries to save Mrs. Lewton is also the most suspenceful scene in the film and the airplane premonition is also one of the best opening scenes I've seen in the movie and the most suspenceful scene in the film and there are other scenes also that are really suspenceful which I totally enjoyed watching in the movie so far. What I also like about this movie is that the whole film has a really unique atmosphere that gives the movie a dark feel and this movie totally had the best cinematography used in a Horror film and I totally enjoyed the film's deliberate atmosphere and overall the atmosphere is well used in the movie so far. The other things that I like about this film is that the whole movie is also full of characters that are well developed and all of the characters are believable and likable at the same time and I as fund of some of the characters in this film some of them were fun and some were just believable which I seriously like in the movie and I seriously like the idea of this film so far. The other highlights I totally enjoyed in this movie is mostly the death scenes in this film. Although the deaths in this movie may not be as gory as the later on Final Destination sequels death scenes the kills are still inventive and painful to watch there's only one death scene where the gore was used once only. Tod's death scene where he gets strangled by the wire while he's hanging his clothes in the bathroom is one of the most painful death scenes in the film. Terry's death is one of the most intense kills in this film. Billy Hitchcock's decapitation death scene was pretty impressive and it may not be gory but it is overall the most suspenceful death scene in the film while Mrs. Lewton's death is the goriest death scene I've seen in the film and I think it is the most gruesome death scene in the film so far because it is the only death scene that used gore only because the rest of the death scenes didn't have any gore although they're all fun to watch so far in the film. Now the acting is great the performances of the casts did a really good job with their work in the film. Devon Sawa did a really good job with his role as the protagonist Alex Browning and his performance in the film is just impressive. Ali Larter did a good job as well with her role in the film as Alex's love interest Clear Rivers. Kerr Smith did a unique and impressive job with his work in the film as the hot headed bully and rival of Alex Carter Horton and Seann William Scott did a good job with his role as Billy Hitchcock an overall all of the casts did a wonderful job with their work in the film so far. Director James Wong did a really good job with his work in this movie and I was impressed with his stylish directing on this film even Glen Morgan and Final Destination series creator Jeffrey Riddick did a good job in making the first installment in the Final Destination series and they totally nailed they're work in the film so far and I was overall impressed with the ideas of the filmmakers in making this movie so far. Overall Final Destination gets a 10/10 because this movie delivers the goods and it has a lot of impressive ideas and big surprises that can wow the audience. I highly recommend you to watch this movie and consider it as an entertaining time killer if you're looking for a good time to get scared and freak out and if you're also interested to watch a lot of kills that will make you jump and squirm.

Alex has a terrifying premonition that causes him and several of his classmates to be escorted off of their plane to Paris just moments before it takes off and explodes. Now, Death has returned to reclaim the victims that escaped their fiery demise... FINAL DESTINATION: The ultimate excuse for contrived screenwriting! The FINAL DESTINATION series gave the typical Teen Slasher an all-new angle that moves away from the hockey-masked killer and into the realm of the supernatural. The films are always about surprise and anticipation, not so much in regards to who is going to die, but when and how. The first FINAL DESTINATION provides thrilling shocks in every death that defy audience expectations. Clever clues are laid out for both the characters and the audience to determine the next method of execution, and yet each death arrives with a sudden jolt. Director James Wong puts together another clean-cut cast of familiar teen faces, with Devon Sawa in the lead as the paranoid Alex Browning and Ali Larter chasing closing behind him as the stereotypically strange and misunderstood Clear Rivers. As silly and absurd as the series often may be, it provides plenty of mindless entertainment as we anxiously await each bloody new death.

It has a great concept that really could have been scary, but it takes on the wrong tone and suffers from being underdeveloped. It winds up being a brain-dead movie aimed at teens, which is a total lost opportunity. It gets off to a strong start where a premonition creates a wrinkle in death's design by a group of people get off a plane before it blows up. An effective and darkly ironic sense of fate comes into play where death will correct no matter what you do to avoid it. You soon know what will happen but you do not know how, and that is unnerving. Sadly, the good setup is only amounts to one senseless kill scene after another. The fundamental flaw of the movie is that the viewer is emotionally detached from nearly all of these characters, so that you will enjoy the process of them dying off on at a time. If you do not care about any of the characters it is hard to care about anything that happens in the movie. Another misstep was how the death scenes are over the top and too farfetched to take seriously. They unfortunately come off as darkly humorous rather than frightening. This movie is misguided and a really good concept is squandered and it results in a mediocre series of kill scenes.

http://expletivedleted.livejournal.com/133284.html What's your favorite scary movie? Well, it depends on how you want to define scary movie. My favorite horror franchise is a toss up between Final Destination and Scream. If we're sticking to the slasher subgenre, it's Scream. I love how it's a sorta parody of the genre, while still being a part of the genre itself. But in the end, I had to go with Final Destination. As a franchise, I feel tht it did stay pretty strong throughout. Yes, it had a few questionable entries, but it didn't decline as steadily or steeply as Scream. The first FD is brilliant. It's the right combo of campy and scary. It's dark and twisted, but a lil tongue-in-cheek and entertainly over the top. The second film continued that grave and austere vibe. The third and fourth did go a bit downhill, too much on the camp and too ridiculous, even for its predecessors. But then the fifth one, just when all hope had been lost, was incredible. It hit the balance even better. Was just as dark as the first two, but just as fun as the last two. That was all well and good, but the twist at the end. Whoa. Beyond perfection. Did not see it coming, and it was a great way to tie everything in. That restored my faith, and that's why Final Destination (mostly the first one, but as a representation of all of them) is on my list. Two things that really stick out to me about these films. One is that the death scenes are really creative. In the early movies they're incredibly creepy and suspenseful. By the later ones, they're more ridiculous, but that's the charm. Half of the fun in watching is seeing how they're gonna die, and the build up gets milked like crazy. However, what really strikes me most about these movies is that the concept scares the \m/ outta me. I don't typically get scared with horror movies, usually because I can see a way out. Slasher movie? Um, run from the guy with the knife, and not to the upstairs bathroom. Shark in the water? Stay outta the water. Supernatural being haunting your house? Right. But here, you're running from death itself. When it's your turn, there is no escape. Even if you're lucky enough to get skipped, it comes back around. Sometimes our victims think they've found a loophole, but by the end (or the next movie) they're still wiped out. The first time I ever saw this movie, it was about two weeks before getting on a plane to fly aross the country for a class trip. I obsessively checked the latch on my tray table to make sure it didn't break off. To this day, I still check it as soon as I sit down. God only knows what I'd do if it ever broke on me. On that same trip, after being edgy about the plane ride, the toilet in one of our hotel rooms overflowed. The water appeared to chase us around the bathroom. I love the original cast so much too. Devon Sawa had been one of my biggest crushes in junior high,a nd this was one of the first times I saw him all growed up. I still adore the boy. He's why I started watching Nikita. This was also during the Dawson's Creek heyday, so it was a big deal seeing Kerr Smith. Roswell was also just starting up, so Brendan Fehr had a small role. You also got Seann William Scott before he was too typecast as Stiffler. And look, a pre-Heroes, pre-blonde Ali Larter! Say what you will about these films being too silly or cheesey. That's what I love about them. http://www.expletivedleted.com http://www.twitter.com/expletivedleted http://www.facebook.com/expletivedleted

Suspenseful and frightening, Final Destination is an entertaining and well-crafted thriller. The story follows a group of high school students that are stalked by Death after a premonition helps them escape a plane crash. The casting is fairly solid, and includes Kerr Smith, Ali Larter, Seann William Scott, and Tony Todd. Additionally, the film does a pretty good job at setting up suspenseful and intense scenes that are unnerving. However, there's some weak writing (particularly the dialog) that cause the tone to be a bit uneven. Yet even with its flaws, Final Destination is a smart film that's full of shocks and scares.
The death scenes are great, but the acting and characters in Final Destination are mainly boring.

Final Destination manages to make the mundane enthralling. That speaks to the quality of thriller that it is, doesn't it? To say that it manages to make someone lighting a candle must-see material tells you just how captivated I was. Sure, a lot of the film features a bunch of red herrings, but when you're having this much fun watching and waiting for people to die, being tricked from time to time isn't a negative. The hook: A class trip to Paris is planned. On the trip, one character sees the plane explode, and thinks he's a goner. But he wakes up, unaware that he had just fallen asleep while waiting for takeoff. He causes a stir, gets a few people kicked off the plane with him, and low and behold, he was right: The plan explodes shortly after getting off the ground. The characters still at the airport should be ecstatic: They just cheated Death! They're alive, and it's all thanks to this premonition. Instead, they're saddened because their friends and classmates just died. Way to keep a somber tone, Final Destination. Anyway, the main character, Alex (Devon Sawa) soon becomes the prime suspect of the FBI. Why? Well, since he had this vision of the future, and managed to get off the plane, they think that he managed to blow it up. They become even more suspicious when his friend, Tod (Chad Donella) commits suicide via hanging himself in the bathroom. Or, at least, that's what the FBI thinks. We saw the truth: A leaky toilet caused water to get on the floor, which in turn lead to Tod slipping, falling toward the bathtub, and getting a wire wrapped around his neck. He struggled but was unable to get free. The water later retreated. We know it wasn't suicide, and we know Alex wasn't involved, but nobody else does. Soon enough, another one of the survivors is killed, once again in an "accident" that Alex can be linked to. The FBI are now thinking he very well could be a serial killer. Meanwhile, the one person who believes him, a woman named Clear (Ali Larter), is trying to help Alex make sense of all of the events that are going on. Essentially, they determine that Death is angry that he didn't take all of the people he planned to, and is now going to get even by killing them later on. So, yes, this elaborate set-up was a way to give director James Wong and writers Glen Morgan and Jeffery Reddick a reason to kill a bunch of teenagers without creating a serial killer to do it. Well, Death can be called a serial killer, I suppose, given the fact that he kind of kills everyone ever alive, but he isn't your traditional knife-to-the-chest killer. Instead, can strike at any time, in any place, using anything. He's possibly the worst entity to make angry. Because of the "any place, any time, anything" problem, absolutely anything the characters do could kill them -- usually in the most complex and Rube Goldberg-esque way possible. For instance, lighting a candle could somehow make fishing hook become stuck in your mouth, pulling you onto an electrocution trap set because your faucet was leaking and you never noticed it. That doesn't actually happen in the film, but it's the best I can come up with at the moment. The logic doesn't always make sense, but the thrill of the kill is never not enjoyable. Since any action taken could trigger an overly complex death sequence, the entire film is intense. For some reason, there isn't any difference between the before-explosion and after-explosion scenes in terms of style. Before the vision is even had, and before we (presumably) know that this is a horror film, mundane actions are still made to seem scary. This doesn't work at the start, and it would have been nice to see a style shift in the before and after shots in order to fully capture just how tense life would be with Death awaiting your every move. I'm not sure if one is supposed to enjoy a film like Final Destination. I wondered throughout if I was supposed to like seeing teenagers getting killed in ways that I can't even describe. Surely this isn't supposed to be fun. But it is. I'm not sure why, but it just is. I wasn't ever scared, but I was engaged. I laughed at some of the kills, as the special effects left a lot to be desired, but because Death could appear at any time to end one of their lives, I had a good time. Maybe that speaks to the viewer's nature -- if you like this kind of film you're a bad person or something -- but I can't deny that the creative kills were fun to watch. This is a film that does get very silly at times, especially later on when the characters think they figure out a way to cheat Death for good. The eventual explanation comes across as both pointless and stupid, even if it does give the characters something to do. It didn't seem necessary, though, as the plot is basically just an excuse to massacre teenagers. If you're enjoying the earlier part of the film, you're not going to want to see these kids live anyway. If you're not, then a "we might be able to avoid Death by doing X" won't save this movie for you. Final Destination is ultimately a very enjoyable film -- if you enjoy watching teenagers die in random, complex and fascinating ways. If you have, I don't know, a shred of empathy for human beings, this might not be for you. But I had a really fun time with it and would recommend it for fans of the teen slasher genre. Death makes a pretty good murderer, when you think about it.

"Final Destination" es junto con "Scream", "I Know What You Did Last Summer" y "Urban Legend", otro intento por revivir el "Slasher movie" tan popular en los 80. En este caso, el asesino es invisible, pero igual persigue a los adolescentes para eliminarlos uno por uno. El merito de esta cinta esta en su ritmo y en que intenta superar los cliches del subgenero. El resultado no llega a ser del todo satisfactorio, pero logra entretener.

Ahh, Final Destination, the movie that started the now never-ending franchise. I remember getting this on dvd and not really knowing what this was going into it. So, we meet Alex and his friends fixing to take a huge trip to Paris. Sounds pretty boring, but then Alex has a vision of him and his friends dying after the plane explodes. He warns them all and he gets some other people off thinking he's just a loony. But then after take off, what do you know, the plane goes BLAM! So a couple months pass and then it happens, they started dying in mysterious 'accidents'. Come to find out, they were never meant to get off the plane and death is back to finish what it started on the plane. Intriguing, don't you think. This was good, unlike some of the others (The Final Destination). It was original, I had never seen anything like this and thought, "Hey, this is a good movie and ranks high among my favs". It was gory, interesting story, cool deaths, Tony Todd, and likeable characters. Even though it had it's flaws, it's still a solid movie and for that 5/5

Good: A good and original idea, portrays death in an interesting manner, kind of like a slasher film-except you can't see the slasher, good deaths, and oh my it's the guy who played the Candyman! Bad: Pretty bad acting from some. I have to that Final Destination is one of the better horror movies of the 2000s to me. I really enjoy the concept of Final Destination. Death is a force that you cannot escape no matter what. They portray death as almost an intelligent person that is adept at his job and will do everything to get it done. It is difficult to place this in an exact genre, but this could easily be considered a slasher film. It has the same kind of formula, except you just cannot see the killer. This killer is very good at what he does, as the deaths is this movie are highly enjoyable and creative. Although they do not compare to the deaths of later movies, and just other movies of the time. Just a little trivia, the man who plays William Bludworth is the same guy who played the Candyman! How about that?! On the down side there is some pretty bad acting from some. Overall, a movie that should be watched by anyone interested in horror or looking for a scare.
